text: Silence -- complete silence for the urbanite, though the  oncoming darkness is punctuated by the sounds of farm cou a few birds, a distant rumble of thunder from some heavy  clouds on the horizon, a dog's barking. CAMERA PANS the green, squared-off flatland, lit only by fine sunset in its final throes. Then, gradually, startin from nothing, a rumble is heard, quickly growing louder a louder until the sound of a train can be recognized. CAMERA PANS quickly, discovering the railroad line atop a man-made rise of land, and the speeding passenger train i upon us, flashing by with a roar. Then, as if from nowhere, the figure of a man hits the  embankment and rolls crazily down to the bottom into the  thick underbrush alongside the tracks.
It lies in the bushes, still, unmoving -- dead. CAMERA PA AWAY to the quiet peaceful countryside as the sound of th train fades off until there is silence once more. TITLE MUSIC begins with a crash.

A handsome and elegant hotel perched on the mountain-side overlooking the French resort town. A large, open sun dec tables, gaily colored parasols, sun bathers. One of the latter is REGINA LAMPERT, a lovely young girl. She is, besides taking in the sun, involved in her favori activity -- eating. Then -- a dark, ominous shape intrudes in the f.g. FOCUS  CHANGES to bring into sharp relief a revolver -- shining, black and ugly in the sunlight. REGGIE, unaware of her danger, continues to eat. The finger tightens around the trigger and finally the gu shoots -- a stream of water arcs, with unerring aim, stra into REGGIE's face.
Including JEAN-LOUIS, a French boy of six or so. REGGIE l at him sternly.
(in for trouble) Oh, la.
Don't tell me you didn't know it was  loaded. (calling) Sylvie!
SYLVIE GAUDET, French, attractive, blonde, in her early  thirties, comes from the railing of the sun deck to join  REGGIE and JEAN-LOUIS.
Isn't there something constructive  he can do -- like start an avalanche?
(to JEAN-LOUIS) Va jouer, mon ange.
JEAN-LOUIS scampers off, content to have gotten off so  lightly. SYLVIE notices REGGIE's lunch which consists of  cold chicken, potato salad, rolls and butter, wine and co
When you start to eat like this  something is the matter.
No answer from REGGIE. SYLVIE begins reading a magazine a REGGIE continues eating.
Sylvie -- I'm getting a divorce.
Ca alors! From Charles?
He's the only husband I've got. I  tried to make it work, I really have --  but --
But what?
I don't know how to explain it. I'm  just too miserable.
REGGIE picks up a chicken leg and starts off. SYLVIE rega the devastated table before following.
It is infuriating that your  unhappiness does not turn to fat!
A magnificent indoor, glass-enclosed pool, the vista of s covered mountains seen through the ceiling-high windows  beyond. REGGIE and SYLVIE are passing through, their  conversation continuing.
But why do you want a divorce?
Because I don't love him.
But that is no reason to get a  divorce!
An open balcony running around two sides of the pool, sun worshippers lying in deck-chairs. REGGIE and SYLVIE appea their conversation continuing.
With a rich husband and this year's  clothes you will not find it difficult  to make some new friends.

(sitting) I admit I moved to Paris because I  was tired of American Provincial, but that doesn't mean I'm ready for  French Traditional. I loathe the  idea of divorce, Sylvie, but -- if  only Charles had been honest with me --  that's all I ask of anybody -- the  simple truth. But with him, everything  is secrecy and lies. He's hiding  something -- something frightening --  something terrible -- and evil.
She stops as she is aware of a weird figure hovering over her. She wheels, terrified.
A strange, grotesque knitted mask that completely covers face except for eyes, nose and mouth. The eyes inside thi particular mask stare down at REGGIE.
Does this belong to you?
CAMERA PANS down to include JEAN-LOUIS, his hand held fir by the man in the mask.
Including REGGIE, MAN, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS. REGGIE is t terrified to answer. Realizing this, the man, PETER JOSHU takes off the snow-mask to reveal a handsome, tanned face
Oh, forgive me. (indicating JEAN-LOUIS) Is this yours?
(indicating SYLVIE) It's hers. Where'd you find him,  robbing a bank?
He was throwing snowballs at Baron  Rothschild. (a pause) We don't know each other, do we?
Why, do you think we're going to?
I don't know -- how would I know?
I'm afraid I already know a great  many people. Until one of them dies  I couldn't possibly meet anyone else.
(smiling) Yes, of course. But you will let me  know if anyone goes on the critical  list (he starts off)
Quitter.
(turning) How's that?
You give up awfully easy, don't you?
Eyeing one, then the other, SYLVIE sizes up the situation and rises.
Viens, Jean-Louis, let us take a  walk. I have never seen a Rothschild  before.
SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS start off, but not before the boy  squirts PETER with his pistol.
(drying) Clever fellow -- almost missed me.
I'm afraid you're blocking my view.
(moving) Sorry. Which view would you like?
The one you're blocking. This is the  last chance I have -- I'm flying  back to Paris this afternoon. What's  your name?
Peter Joshua.
I'm Regina Lampert.
Is there a Mr. Lampert?
Yes.
Good for you.
No, it isn't. I'm getting a divorce.
Please, not on my account.
No, you see, I don't really love  him.
Well, you're honest, anyway.
Yes, I am -- I'm compulsive about it --  dishonesty infuriates me. Like when  you go into a drugstore.
I'm not sure I --

Well, you go in and you ask for some  toothpaste -- the small size -- and  the man brings you the large size.  You tell him you wanted the small  size but he says the large size is  the small size. I always thought the  large size was the largest size, but  he says that the family size, the  economy size and the giant size are  all larger than the large size --  that the large size is the smallest  size there is.
Oh. I guess.
Is there a Mrs. Joshua?
Yes, but we're divorced.
That wasn't a proposal -- I was just  curious.
Is your husband with you?
Oh, Charles is hardly ever with me.  First it was separate rooms -- now  we're trying it with cities. What do  people call you -- Pete?
Mr. Joshua. (turning to go) Well, I've enjoyed talking with you.
Now you're angry.
No, I'm not -- I've got some packing  to do. I'm also going back to Paris  today.
Oh. Well, wasn't it Shakespeare who  said: "When strangers do meet they  should erelong see one another again"?
Shakespeare never said that.
How do you know?
It's terrible -- you just made it  up.
Well, the idea's right, anyway. Are  you going to call me?
Are you in the book?
Charles is.
Is there only one Charles Lampert?
Her face clouding.
Lord, I hope so.
The Arc de Triomphe at the far end of the Avenue. CAMERA  PANS to pick up a TAXI as it pulls up before the handsome building. Inside are REGGIE, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS.
As REGGIE climbs out and the DRIVER begins unloading her  suitcases.
Goodbye, Sylvie, and thanks. (She turns toward the  house)
JEAN-LOUIS sticks his head out of the taxi window.
When you get your divorce will you  be going back to America?
REGGIE looks at SYLVIE, surprised.
He knows everything.
(to JEAN-LOUIS) Don't you want me to stay?
Yes, of course -- but if you went  back and wrote me a letter --
-- you could have the stamps. I'll  get you some here, okay?
Okay.
REGGIE walks toward the house with the driver, who carrie her cases.  She presses the button that electrically open the front door.
As the elevator rises REGGIE gets out, followed by the dr He puts down the bags in front of the apartment door.
(handing him a tip) Merci.

The driver leaves. She goes to the door and presses the  minuterie, the button that turns on the time-light, and t lights come on. Then she rings the doorbell. There is no  answer. She rings again. Still nothing. Sighing, she digs out her keys and starts to fit it into the lock. At this  moment the minuterie expires, plunging the scene into  darkness.
Wonderful.
She finds the button and the light goes on again. She ins the key and turns it.
CLOSE SHOT -- DOOR as it opens and REGGIE steps into the  CLOSE SHOT. She stops, her expression changing.
From REGGIE's p.o.v. as CAMERA PANS the entrance hall. It bare -- no furniture, no rug, no pictures, no nothing.
She stares for a moment, then goes back out into the land
As REGGIE steps back outside. She looks at the nameplate  beside the door.
It reads "MR. AND MRS. CHARLES LAMPERT."
REGGIE looks at the plate in disbelief, then turns and hu back into the apartment.
As REGGIE hurries into the entrance hall.
Honorine -- !

No answer. Now, CAMERA FOLLOWING, she goes into the Salon. It is als empty -- stripped bare. There are squares of the wall's  original color where paintings used to hang, the hooks st in the wall. She rushes now, going into the bedroom, CAMERA FOLLOWING  crazily, lurching and careening behind her. The bedroom,  too, is empty. She goes to the built-in wardrobe closets throws open all the doors. Only some hangers remain. She pulls open the drawers -- nothing!
Charles -- !

She turns, and running now, goes through another door to library, CAMERA FOLLOWING. The rows of shelves are as emp as the rest of the apartment. She begins to turn in a cir looking for something, anything. In a panic she turns and runs out, colliding suddenly with a MAN whom she (and we) have not noticed until the moment of impact. REGGIE screams.
A heavy-set man of no particular age with tobacco-colored hair, and thick glasses.
Madame Charles Lampert?
Including REGGIE, in a state of near-shock.
Yes.
I am Inspector Edouard Grandpierre  of the Police Judiciaire. Would you  be so kind as to come with me, please?
We see a large metal drawer being opened and an all-too-  familiar shape outlined under a damp sheet of muslin.

Looking straight down at the tops of REGGIE's, GRANDPIERR and an ATTENDANT's head and smack into the open drawer. GRANDPIERRE lifts a corner of the sheet at the bottom and reveals a bare foot with a ticket tied to its big toe. He stoops to read it. Satisfied, he recovers the foot, th moves to the other end to uncover the head.  As the sheet starts to lift:
REGGIE as she looks down into the CAMERA. She closes her  eyes for a moment, then looks again.
Well, Madame -- ?
She nods.
You are positive?
She nods again. GRANDPIERRE moves into the SHOT.
You loved him?
I'm very cold.
GRANDPIERRE nods as he turns to the unseen ATTENDANT. CAMERA suddenly moves as the 'drawer' is slid back into t wall. BLACKNESS comes with a loud clang and continues whi the echo dies.
CLOSE SHOT -- DESK DRAWER (FROM ABOVE) as it is pulled op A photograph of Charles Lampert lies face up in the drawe A hand reaches in and pulls it out.
Including GRANDPIERRE sitting behind his desk, and REGGIE sitting across from him. The office is as bare as most  policemen's offices. GRANDPIERRE studies the photo.

We discovered your husband's body  lying next to the tracks of the Paris- Bourdeaux railroad line. He was  dressed only in his pajamas. Do you  know of any reason why he might have  wished to leave France?
Leave?
Your husband possessed a ticket of  passage on the 'Maranguape.' It sailed  from Bordeaux for Maracaibo this  morning at seven.
(a pause) I'm very confused.

She starts to rummage through her bag. GRANDPIERRE shoves package of French cigarettes across the desk to her. But pulls a package of nuts out of her bag. She begins separa the shells with her thumb nail and eating the nuts, depos the shells in the ashtray. GRANDPIERRE watches this for a instant.
He was American?
Swiss.
Oh. Swiss. His profession?
He didn't have one.
He was a wealthy man?
I don't know. I suppose so.
About how wealthy would you say?
I don't know.
Where did he keep his money?
I don't know.
Besides yourself, who is his nearest  relation?
I don't know.
(exploding) C'est absurde, Madame. To-tale-ment  absurde!
I know. (pause) I'm sorry.
It is all right.
GRANDPIERRE sighs, puts down his pencil and pushes a butt on the desk. He removes a cigar from his desk and inserts into his mouth.
Is it all right?
I wish you wouldn't.
He rips the cigar out of his mouth and slams it back into the drawer, closing it fiercely. A UNIFORMED POLICEMAN st his head in the door.
Les effets de Lampert.
The POLICEMAN leaves and closes the door.

On Wednesday last your husband sold  the entire contents of the apartment  at public auction. Furniture,  clothing, kitchenware -- everything.  The gallery, in complying with his  wishes, paid him in cash. One million  two hundred and fifty thousand New  Francs. In dollars, a quarter of a  million. The authorities in Bordeaux  have searched his compartment on the  train. They have searched it  thoroughly. They did not find  $250,000, Madame.

He opens the desk drawer, puts the cigar back in his mout and lights a match by scratching it against the glass des top before he remembers REGGIE's request. He puts it back the drawer again. The door opens and the POLICEMAN enters again, this time carrying a wicker basket which he deposi on GRANDPIERRE's desk, and leaves. GRANDPIERRE peers into the basket.
These few things are all that was  found in the train compartment. There  was no other baggage. Your husband  must have been in a great hurry.
He begins to take them out, placing them on the desk,  identifying each item as he does.

One wallet containing four thousand  francs -- one agenda -- (pausing, he opens  the notebook) -- his last notation was made  yesterday -- Thursday -- (reading) "Five p.m. -- Jardin des Champs- Elysees" (looking up) Why there?
I don't know. Perhaps he met somebody.
(dryly) Obviously. (returning to the  items in the basket) One ticket of passage to South America --  one letter, stamped but unsealed,  addressed to you --
(lighting up) A letter? May I see it?
GRANDPIERRE hands her the letter and watches her closely she reads it.

(reading) "My dear Regina: I hope you are  enjoying your holiday. Megeve can be  so lovely this time of year. The  days pass very slowly and I hope to  see you soon. As always, Charles.  P.S. Your dentist called yesterday.  Your appointment has been changed." (she looks up, puzzled) Not very much, is it?
We took the liberty of calling your  dentist -- we thought, perhaps, we  would learn something.
Did you?

Yes. Your appointment has been  changed. (he smiles at his  little joke, then  returns to the basket) One key to your apartment -- one  comb -- one fountain pen --  one  toothbrush -- one tin of tooth powder (he looks up) -- that is all.
He slides a sheet of paper and pen across to her, then st to put the things back into the basket while he speaks:
If you will sign this list you may  take the things with you.
(sighing) Is that all? Can I go now?
One more question. Is this your  husband's passport?
He reaches into the desk drawer and pulls out a passport  which he hands to her.
The cover indicates that it is Swiss. REGGIE's hand opens to a picture of a man -- the man we saw in GRANDPIERRE's  photo. Under it is the name: "CHARLES LAMPERT."
Of course it is.
And this?
He hands her another passport.
The cover is American. When it is opened, we see the iden picture, but the name under it reads: "CHARLES VOSS."
I don't understand.
And this? And this?
He hands her, one at a time, two more passports.
One is Italian which, when opened, shows the same photo w the name "CARLO FABRI." The other is Venezuelan, the same photo, and the name "CARLOS MORENO."
Have you nothing to say, Madame?
REGGIE looks down at the four passports, then back to  GRANDPIERRE.
(hopefully) It's all right if you want to smoke  your cigar now.

The house is empty as before. Now it is silent, the late  afternoon light coming from outside. REGGIE stands by a  window. A canvas airline bag rests on the floor nearby. Suddenly there is the noise of a DOOR OPENING.
As her head turns, in alarm, toward the noise. There is a moment of silence, then FOOTSTEPS are heard, coming close
As PETER enters.
(surprised) What are you doing here?
I phoned but nobody answered. I wanted  to tell you how sorry I am -- and to  find out if there was anything I  could do.
How did you find out?
It's in all the afternoon papers.  I'm very sorry.
Thank you.
A silence.
I rang the bell but I don't think  it's working.
Yes it is -- I heard it this morning.
He looks around for the light switch, then goes to it and flicks it on -- nothing happens. He flicks it a few more  times.
They must have turned off the  electricity.
She shakes her head. PETER looks around.
Where did everything go?
Charles sold it all -- at auction.
Do you know what you're going to do?
Try and get my old job back at UNESCO,  I suppose.
Doing what?
I'm a simultaneous translator --  like Sylvie, only she's English to  French -- I'm French to English.  That's what I did before I married  Charles. The police probably think I  killed him.
Instant divorce you mean?
Something like that. But I'm sorry  it ended like this -- tossed off a  train like a sack of third-class  mail.
(Taking her hand) Come on. You can't stay here.
I don't know where to go.
We'll find you a hotel.
Not too expensive -- I'm not a lady  of leisure anymore.
Something modest but clean -- and  near enough to UNESCO so you can  take a cab when it rains -- okay?
She nods. He picks up the airlines bag and they start out REGGIE stops at the door and looks back.
I loved this room -- but Charles  never saw it -- only what was in it.  All those exquisite things -- (looking around) I think I prefer it like this.
CLOSE SHOT of a phonograph. A hand appears, starts the re on it spinning, then places the arm at the beginning. An instant later ORGAN MUSIC starts with a roar.

CLOSE SHOT of the coffin. It rests on a low platform, wit bouquet or two of flowers near the head, the lid open. Inside, the face made up to look lifelike (but failing), the remnants of Charles Lampert.

The INSPECTOR sits quietly, eyes downcast, staring at his hands in a prayer-like attitude. CAMERA PULLS BACK, revea row after row of empty wooden bench-like seats in the lar dimly-lit, high-ceilinged room. Finally, in the first row REGGIE and SYLVIE are discovered. Besides GRANDPIERRE, th are the only ones present. REGGIE turns around to look at the empty room. They speak in whispers.
It's not exactly what I'd call a  large turn-out.
Didn't Charles have any friends?
Don't ask me -- I'm only the widow. (indicating GRANDPIERRE) If Charles had died in bed we wouldn't  even have him.
At least he knows how to behave at  funerals.
His eyes still lowered. CAMERA PANS DOWN to feature his h he is methodically trimming his nails with a small clippe
Have you no idea who could have done  it?
Until two days ago all I really knew  about Charles was his name -- now it  turns out I didn't even know that.
The front DOOR of the Chapel is heard opening and a shaft daylight streams in. The WOMEN turn.

The short, heavy-set figure of a MAN is outlined against bright outdoor light. He stands for a moment, then closes the door after him. LEOPOLD GIDEON, short-sighted, bald, his middle forties, glances around nervously, like a barn bird. Then he walks down one of the side aisles of the Ch
As he watches GIDEON.
As she watches him.

GIDEON arrives at the coffin. He stops, looks down at  LAMPERT's body for a moment. Then, suddenly, in rapid  succession, he sneezes six times. He takes a small bottle from his pocket, shakes a pill from it and swallows it dr He turns and walks back up the aisle, looking for a place sit. He comes face to face with GRANDPIERRE, stops, turns sit somewhere else.
Do you know him?
I've never seen him before.
He must have known Charles pretty  well.
How can you tell?
He's allergic to him.
SYLVIE turns and glances at GIDEON. Again, the sound of t DOOR opening interrupts them. They turn to look.

Again the figure of a MAN is outlined in silhouette again the outside brightness. When he closes the door we can se "TEX" PENTHOLLOW, a slim, rangy man with sandy-colored ha a weatherbeaten face, washed-out blue-eyes -- also in his forties. He wears a velvet-corduroy suit, string tie and bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier, CAMERA LEADING  him, and we notice his unsteady gait. He turns to look at the others present. TRAVELING SHOT -- TEX'S P.O.V. MOVING down the aisle. GRANDPIERRE's face, then GIDEON's, then REGGIE's and SYLVIE's -- all staring at CAMERA.

As TEX arrives. He stands staring at LAMPERT's body, sway on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of th coffin to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from h lapel and throws it into the open box.
(heavy Texas accent) Ariva durchy, Charlie.
As TEX turns away from the coffin and approaches REGGIE a SYLVIE, addressing the latter -- after having first reach for his hat which he discovers he isn't wearing.
Miz Lampert, ma'am...
SYLVIE points to REGGIE. Unruffled, TEX starts over.  addressing REGGIE this time.
Miz Lampert, ma'am...
Yes?
Charlie had no call to handling it  this-a-way. He sure didn't. No siree.
I don't understa--
But TEX has nodded his head and moved off to find a seat. When he spots GIDEON, the two men stare at each other. Finally, TEX chooses a seat away from him and sits.
It flies open, this time with a bang, and the large MAN w appears almost fills the frame.
As the loud noise awakens him with a snort, mid-snore.

Closing the door, we see HERMAN SCOBIE, a heavy-weight -- tall and wide, but not fat -- with black hair combed stra back and heavy bushy eyebrows of a matching color, which  meet over his nose and join up. About the same age as the first two men, SCOBIE is dressed in a battered raincoat, hands thrust deep in the pockets. He marches down the ais Looking straight ahead, CAMERA PANNING with him. He stops before the coffin and stares into it.

As he stares down into the coffin, his tongue trying to  dislodge a bit of food caught in his teeth. He stares har at the body, squinting his eyes. Then he removes one hand from his pocket, removes a pin from the inside of his lap picks his teeth with it, then slowly lets the hand down,  into the coffin.
The pin held between thumb and forefinger, he jabs it slo but positively deep into the back of one of the dead man' hands. There is no reaction.
He watches the dead man carefully, still squinting. Then  finally satisfied, he returns the pin to his lapel and wa back up the aisle and out of the door, slamming it after  him.
Having watched SCOBIE exit. Suddenly a hand falls on her  shoulder. She jumps in alarm and utters a little cry of  fright.

Featuring a funeral ATTENDANT, a cadaverous type (aren't  they all) with a black cut-away coat and an over-solicito unctuous manner. He is eternally bent at the waist, in a  sort of half bow. He offers REGGIE a letter which she tak
Merci, Monsieur.
Pas du tout, madame, pardon -- pardon --  pardon.
He backs off and is gone. REGGIE looks at the letter, bac and front, then starts to open it.
Who is it from?
The American Embassy.
She pulls out the letter and starts to read it.

It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead and the typed mes reads: "Dear Mrs. Lampert: Please drop by my office tomorrow at  noon-thirty. I am anxious to discuss the matter of your l husband's death. Sincerely, (signed) H. Bartholomew."
SYLVIE has been reading over REGGIE's shoulder.
What is it about?
I don't know.  But if this is a sample  of American diplomacy I'm buying a  fallout shelter.
The fine old building in the Rue Gabriel.
As REGGIE leaves the elevator two young DIPLOMATIC TYPES  step in, immersed in conversation.
I bluffed the Old Man out of the  last pot -- with a pair of deuces.
What's so depressing about that?
If I can do it, what are the Russians  doing to him?
The elevator door closes on them. REGGIE reacts to this a starts down the hall, finally stopping at the door.
It is marked "307-A  H. BARTHOLOMEW." REGGIE checks the  letter, then opens the door.
The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's de is covered with its plastic shroud. REGGIE enters, looks somebody, notices that the door to the private office is  slightly ajar.
(tentatively) Hello -- ? (there is no answer) Hello?
(from the private  office) Is there anything wrong, Miss  Tompkins?
Uh -- Miss Tompkins isn't here.

BARTHOLOMEW comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale  grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older th his forty-odd years. Sickly would be the word that descri him best -- pallid, consumptive-looking. He wears heavy  tortoise-framed glasses which fall down his nose and caus him to push them back in place every so often with a quic automatic motion.
I'm sorry -- my secretary must have  gone to lunch. You are -- ?
Mrs. Lampert -- Mrs. Charles Lampert.
(looking at his watch) Come in, Mrs. Lampert. You're quite  late.
He motions for her to enter, standing aside to let her do so.

A small cubicle -- there is a silver-framed photo of thre kids on the desk. BARTHOLOMEW indicates a chair, then goe behind his desk and sits. A can of lighter fluid stands o on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it.
Excuse me for a moment, Mrs. Lampert --  it's a stubborn little devil.
He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie.
Dry-cleaningwise, things are all  fouled up. I had a good man -- an  excellent man on the Rue Ponthieu,  but H.Q. asked us to use the plant  here in the building -- to ease the  gold outflow.
Mr. Bartholomew -- are you sure you  know who I am?
(looking up) Charles Lampert's widow -- yes? (going back to the  tie) Last time I sent out a tie only the  spot came back.
He looks up at her, laughs silently, then goes back to hi tie.
Voila! As they say.

He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, smells t hankie, passes on it, then sticks it in his pocket. He opens another drawer and pulls out various sandwiches  wrapped in waxpaper, a salt and pepper shaker, a tube of  mustard, a bottle of red wine and two Dixie cups.
Have some, please. I've got... (checking) ...liverwurst -- liverwurst -- chicken  and -- liverwurst.
No thanks.
He uncorks the wine, fills a cup and begins eating.
Do you know what C.I.A. is, Mrs.  Lampert?
I don't suppose it's an airline, is  it?
Central Intelligence Agency -- C.I.A.
You mean spies and things like that?
Only we call them agents.
We? You mean you're --?
Someone has to do it, Mrs. Lampert --
I'm sorry, it's just that I didn't  think that you people were supposed  to admit --
I'm not an agent, Mrs. Lampert --  I'm an administrator -- a desk jockey --  trying to run a bureau of overworked  men with under-allocated funds.  Congress seems to think that all a  spy needs --
Agent.
Yes -- That all he needs is a code  book and a cyanide pill and he's in  business.
What's all this got to do with me,  Mr. Bartholomew?
(his mouth full) Your husband was wanted by the U. S.  government.
May I have a sandwich, please?
He hands her a sandwich and fills a wine-cup for her.
To be more specific, he was wanted  by this agency.
(eating) So that was it.
Yes. We knew him, of course, by his  real name.
(almost choking) His -- real -- ?

Voss -- Charles Voss. All right,  Mrs. Voss -- (taking a photo from  his desk) -- I'd like you to look at this  photograph, please -- by the way,  you saw this one, didn't you? (indicating the kids  on the desk) Scott, Cathy, and Ham, Jr.
Very sweet.
Aren't they?  Now look at this one,  Mrs. Voss, and --
Stop calling me that! Lampert's the  name on the marriage license.
Yes -- and tell me if you recognize  anyone. Just a moment. Have a good  look.
He reaches back into the drawer and pulls out a glass whi he gives her.
FOUR MEN, all in army uniform, sitting behind a table. Th glass is held over the first, magnifying the face.
It's a photo of a young CHARLES LAMPERT.
It's Charles!
Very good.
He looks so young -- when was this  taken?
1944. The next face, please.
The glass and CAMERA move to the next man -- a young TEX.

Does the name Tex Penthollow mean  anything to you?
No.
Next, please.
The glass and CAMERA move to the third face -- a young GI
Yes -- and he was there, too -- a  little fatter now -- and less hair --  but it's the same one.
Do you know him, Mrs. Vo -- Mrs.  Lampert? Leopold W. Gideon?
No.
The last one, please.
The glass and CAMERA move to the fourth face -- a young  SCOBIE.
That's a face you don't forget -- he  was there too --
Herman Scobie. And you've never seen  him before, either?
No, thank heaven.
(a pause, regarding  her) Mrs. Lampert, I'm afraid you're in a  great deal of danger.
Danger? Why should I be in any danger?
You're Charles Voss's wife -- now  that he's dead you're their only  lead.
Mr. Bartholomew -- if you're trying  to frighten me you're doing a really  first-rate job! (she takes another  sandwich)
Please, do what we ask, Mrs. Lampert --  it's your only chance.
Gladly, only I don't know what you  want! You haven't told me.
Oh, haven't I? The money -- Mrs.  Lampert -- the money. The $250,000  Charles Voss received from the  auction. Those three men want it,  too -- they want it very badly.
But it's Charles's money, not theirs.
(laughing) Oh, Mrs. Lampert! I'd love to see  you try and convince them of that! (drying his eyes) Oh, dear.
Then whose is it? His or theirs?
Ours.
(she looks at him for  a moment) Oh, I see.
And I'm afraid we want it back.
But I don't have it.
That's impossible. You're the only  one who could have it.
I'm sorry it's impossible. It's the  truth.
BARTHOLOMEW is silent for a moment, thinking.
I believe you.
Thanks very much.
Oh, you've got the money all right --  you just don't know you've got it.
Mr. Bartholomew -- if I had a quarter  of a million dollars, believe me,  I'd know it.
Nevertheless, Mrs Lampert -- you've  got it.
You mean it's just lying around  someplace -- all that cash?
Or a safe deposit key, a certified  check, a baggage claim -- you look  for it, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm quite  sure you'll find it.
But --

Look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- look  just as hard and as fast as you can.  You may not have a great deal of  time. Those men know you have it  just as surely as we do. You won't  be safe until the money's in our  hands. Is that clear?
REGGIE nods. He writes something on a pad of paper and te it off, handing it to her.

Here's where you're to call me --  day or night. It's a direct line to  both my office and my apartment.  Don't lose it, Mrs. Lampert -- and  please don't tell anyone about coming  to see me. It could prove fatal for  them as well as yourself.
Wait a minute -- you think those  three men killed Charles, don't you?
We've no proof, of course, but we  rather think so, yes.
Well, there you are! Charles had the  money with him -- so whoever killed  him has it -- they have it!
BARTHOLOMEW shakes his head.
Why not?
(grimly) Because they're still here.
Oh.
Like I said, Mrs Lampert -- I'm afraid  you're in a great deal of danger.  Remember what happened to Charles.

One of the French Punch and Judy shows set up on certain  days in the small park alongside the broad avenue between the Rond Point and the Place de la Concorde. At the momen Judy, as always, is beating Punch with a bat. The sound o CHILDREN laughing and screaming can be heard.

Sitting on small benches lined up to face the stage. Thei attention is fixed on the show, their belief totally susp by the play as only children's can be -- laughing at the  slapstick, booing the villain, frightened by the perils.

Sitting on the last bench, next to some CHILDREN. They ar laughing but she isn't -- she just watches, her attention caught up but her face void of emotion. The bench is too for her, forcing her knees up almost under her chin. After a moment, PETER comes up behind her and, stepping o the benches, sits beside her. She doesn't seem to notice. [Throughout the following scene the CHILDREN and the ACTO can be heard in the b.g.]
Reggie -- ?
She turns and looks at him for a moment.
(vaguely) Hallo, Peter.
You telephoned me to meet you. I've  been standing on the corner back  there -- waiting for you.
I'm sorry -- I heard the children  laughing.
A ROAR from the CHILDREN. REGGIE and PETER turn toward th stage.
PUNCH and JUDY are arguing loudly.
What's going on?
Don't you understand French?
I'm still having trouble with English.
The man and the woman are married --
PUNCH and JUDY are batting each other on the head.
Yes, I can see that -- they're batting  each other over the head with clubs.
Finally, JUDY knocks Punch out of sight and a PUPPET wear a three-cornered hat appears.
Who's that with the hat?
Wearing a hat, he stands off in the background, watching.
That's the policeman -- he wants to  arrest Judy for killing Punch.
JUDY and the POLICEMAN are batting one another.
What's she saying now?
That she's innocent -- she didn't do  it.
She did it, all right -- take it  from me.
I believe her.
PUNCH's head appears on the other side of the stage, says something, then ducks out.
Who was that?
Punch, of course.
Of course? I thought he was dead.
He's only pretending, to teach her a  lesson -- only -- (her face clouding) only he is dead, Peter -- I saw him --  he's not pretending. Somebody threw  him off a train. What am I going to  do?
Charles was mixed up in something terrible.
I wish you'd let me help you. Whatever  it is, it doesn't sound like the  sort of thing that a woman can handle  all by herself.
JUDY has gotten the upper hand is now batting the POLICEM brains out. CLOSE SHOT -- GRANDPIERRE as he winces.
Have you got a mirror? (she nods) Give it to me.
She hands it to him and he holds it in front of her face.
Right there, between your eyes --  see? Worry lines. You're much too  young and too pretty to have anything  like that. How about making me vice- president in charge of cheering you  up?
(jumping at the  suggesting) Starting tonight?
He stands on the dance floor in front of a five piece Lat dance band, a spotlight on him, wearing his professional  smile as he speaks into a mike.

Bonsoir mesdames et messieurs, good  evening ladies and gentlemen, guten  Abend, meine Damen und Herren -- ce  soir, comme tous les soirs,  l'attraction ici, au Black Sheep  Club, c'est vous! Venez, mesdames et  messieurs, step right up, ladies and  gentlemen, kommen Sie her, meine  Damen en Herren, avanti, signore e  signori -- avanti!
At their table. REGGIE is dressed in a lovely Givenchy dr

Fun and games. Evidently we're the  floorshow.

Including the dance floor as most of the patrons go to it laughing self-consciously and looking around.

Ecoutez bien -- les regles sont tres  simples -- the rules are very easy --  deux equipes -- two teams -- each  with one orange -- une orange --  eine apfelsine -- un' arrancia --  held under the chin, like so -- (does it) comme ca -- and passed to the player  behind you -- sans vous servir de  vos mains -- using nothing but the  chin -- no hands -- and keeping the  orange at all costs from touching  the floor. Commencez, Mesdames et  Messieurs -- begin, ladies and  gentlemen -- signore e signori,  comminciate!

The EMCEE now circulates, forming teams, telling the patr to line up, making sure there is a woman next to every ma REGGIE and PETER are the second couple in their line. Then the EMCEE picks up a basket of oranges and places on under the chin, held securely against the chest, of each at the head of the line. Blowing a whistle, a signal for game to begin and the band to play, the men turn to the w behind them and attempt to transfer the oranges from unde their chins to under the chins of the women -- without us their hands. (This maneuver can only be accomplished by embracing one' partner passionately and firmly pressing the orange again the partner's throat until he or she can grip it tightly  enough with the chin to turn and offer it to the person n in line, where the process begins anew. However, the slig miscalculation, which can be brought about by any number human frailties -- haste, modesty, inhibition or lack of ordination -- will surely result in losing control of the orange so that it either falls to the floor [where it can only be picked up by the chin] or it starts to roll and s from its proper place to some other, less proper, spot on the human anatomy, forcing the man or the woman to retrie it -- again, with the chin only. This latter is an activi which can prove extremely satisfying to old friends, or e new friends who wish to become old friends, but can only a torment for total strangers and/or the English).
Some of the couples in various states of confusion,  entanglement and intimacy -- all of them, naturally,  hilarious.

It is his turn to take the orange from a very short, but  quite shapely young girl in a strapless dress (held up by abundance of cantilever). PETER 'takes' when he sees the  twin obstacles which might -- and probably will -- encumb the game but increase his worldly experience. The contest begins: because of her stature he is forced t move in low, making the ordinary embrace needed for succe difficult, if not impossible. Then, inexorably, the orang starts to slip down the GIRL's front. Manfully he goes af it.
She is enjoying it thoroughly.

Bending over backwards, in a sort of frontal half-nelson, PETER makes a last valiant effort and voila, grips the or under his chin -- amid much cheering and congratulations  from members of his TEAM. Now he turns to REGGIE and they face one another for a mo
En garde.
Lay on, MacDuff.

They go at it, working their bodies together to make it a possible. Then, for a moment, the game and the onlookers  seem less important than their proximity. But, alas, they are too good despite themselves and the transfer is  accomplished -- again with appreciative cheers from the T REGGIE, with the orange now tucked firmly under her chin, turns to the next team-member in line and is locked in an embrace before she realizes her partner is LEOPOLD GIDEON the short, fat, balding man seen at the funeral and later BARTHOLOMEW's photo. REGGIE starts to draw back but GIDEON holds her tightly. Putting his chin around the orange he is able to speak qu in REGGIE's ear.
Her eyes show her fright as he whispers:
Mrs. Lampert --
What do you want?
Didn't Charles tell you, Mrs. Lampert?
Tell me what?
It doesn't belong to you, Mrs. Lampert --  you do know that, don't you?
I don't know anything.
Mrs. Lampert, any morning now you  could wake up dead.
Leave me alone -- !
Dead, Mrs. Lampert -- like last week's  news -- like Charles, Mrs. Lampert --
Stop it!
As REGGIE hauls off and kicks GIDEON full in the shin.
He stiffens as the pain registers. Instead of shouting he merely closes his eyes.
Including REGGIE and GIDEON and PETER standing by, as wel as some spectators. PETER comes quickly forward.
Reggie -- what's the trouble?
REGGIE realizes that GIDEON no longer offers any resistan She steps back, leaving GIDEON holding the orange, foolis under his chin, his eyes still closed. REGGIE stares at h for a moment.
He -- he was stepping on my foot.
Slowly, his eyes open and tears stream from them, rolling down his cheeks. He speaks while holding the orange.
Forgive me -- it was quite  unintentional, I'm sure.
GIDEON turns to the woman behind him and the game resumes
(starting off) Wait for me -- I won't be long.
She goes off toward the rear of the club and starts down flight of stairs.
Watching her go, a concerned look on his face.

A small, dimly lit area with a door to the combination me women's room and a 'phone cabin with a solid door. The music and shouting from upstairs float down. REGGIE c down the stairs and goes to the 'phone, flicking on the l and closing the door after her.

REGGIE takes a jeton ('phone token) from her bag and drop it in the slot. Then she takes out a slip of paper (the o given her by BARTHOLOMEW) and dials the number written on it. She listens to it ring, then evidently he answers.
(into 'phone) Mr. Bartholomew -- it's me, Reggie  Lampert -- listen Mr. Bartholomew:  I've seen one of the (she stops) Mr. Bartholomew? Can you hear me?
She realizes she has not pushed the button which takes he coin and allows the party at the other end to hear her vo
Hello -- Mr. Bartholomew -- it's me,  Regina Lam...

TEX PENTHOLLOW, the second man from the funeral (and phot the man in the corduroy suit and string tie, stands in th doorway, his face calm, a hand-rolled but unlit cigarette his mouth. He has put one foot up against the side of the door so she can't leave. REGGIE stares at him, terrified.
Howdy, Miz Lampert.
Wha -- what do you want?
TEX takes a book of matches from his pocket.
You know what I want, Miz Lampert...
No -- no, I'm don't.
Come on now -- sure you do. An' you'd  better give it to me, Miz Lampert --  cuz I ain't foolin'. No sireebob!
He strikes a match and lights his cigarette, holding the  burning match in his hand afterward.
I don't know what --
TEX, without a word, throws the still-lit match into the  booth, onto REGGIE's lap. She beats it out frantically.
What are you doing?
TEX lights another match and throws it into her lap. She  beats this one out too.
Stop that!
Don't make too much noise, Miz Lampert --
He lights another match and reaches out toward her hair w it. She shrinks back.
It could get a whole lot worse.
Then he throws it into her lap. As he continues to speak punctuates each phrase or so with another lit match. REGG is too busy beating them out to do anything else.
It belongs to me, Miz Lampert -- an'  if you don't give it to me your life  ain't gonna be worth the paper it's  printed on. You savvy what I'm sayin',  Miz Lampert?
Please stop -- please!
You think on it real careful-like,  Miz Lampert -- y'hear?
As she frantically beats out the matches, her eyes on her work.
You're insane, absolutely insane!
She looks up, then blinks her eyes.
There is no one there. REGGIE rises and steps out of the  booth.
As REGGIE looks around. There is no one there.

As REGGIE returns, sits and starts to put another jeton i the slot. She notices her hand is shaking. She reaches ba into her bag, removes a piece of candy, puts it into her  mouth and leans her head back against the wall, closing h eyes. Suddenly the door opens and REGGIE shrieks -- but this ti it is PETER.
What are you doing in here?
(a sigh of relief) Having a nervous breakdown.
REGGIE and PETER enter the deserted lobby.
You haven't said a word since we  left the club -- what happened back  there?
I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to  tell you or not.
I don't think I follow you.
He said if I told anybody it could  prove fatal for them as well as me.
Who said?
That's what I'm not supposed to say.
Stop this nonsense! If you're in  some sort of trouble I want to know  about it.
Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying  me.
I wasn't --
Yes, you were -- you called it  nonsense. Being murdered in cold  blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it  happens to you sometime.
She goes to the desk, followed by PETER, where the NIGHT  CLERK greets them sleepily.
Bonsoir.
Bonsoir. Quarante-deux, s'il vous  plait.
The NIGHT CLERK gets the key off a hook and hands it to  REGGIE.
Bonne nuit.
(to PETER) Would you mind seeing me to the door?
Of course not.
They go to the elevator where he opens the door for her.
As REGGIE and PETER enter the small cage. It is somewhat  cramped, forcing them to stand close together.
This is quite a place for making  friends, isn't it?
He presses the button and the elevator starts to rise.
You said this afternoon that your  husband was mixed up in something.
(busy examining the  cleft in his chin) How do you shave in there?
What was it?
What was what?
What your husband was mixed up in.
Look, I know it's asking you to  stretch your imagination, but can't  you pretend for a moment that I'm a  woman and that you're a --
Don't you know I could already be  arrested for transporting a minor  above the first floor?
The elevator stops.
We're here.
Where?
On the street where you live.
How about once more around the park?
He reaches across her and opens the door.
Out.
As REGGIE leaves the elevator, followed by PETER. They wa to her door. There is a moment of silence as she looks at him.

(imitating PETER) Him: 'Do you mind if I come in for a  nightcap, Reggie?' Her: 'Well -- it  is awfully late.' Him: 'Just one,  all right?' Her: 'Promise you'll  behave yourself.' Him: 'Sorry, baby,  I never make promises I can't keep.'
How would you like a spanking?
How would you like a punch in the  nose? Stop treating me like a child.
Then stop acting like one. If you're  really in some kind of trouble, I'd  like to hear about it. Otherwise,  it's late, I'm tired and I'm going  home to bed.
Do you know what's wrong with you?
What?
Nothing. Good night.
Good night.
He turns and leaves. She smiles slightly, then turns and  puts the key into the door and opens it.
Featuring the door. REGGIE enters, then stops abruptly, t doorknob still in her hand.
The room has been torn apart. And standing in the center HERMAN SCOBIE, the large man in the battered raincoat. He starts slowly advancing toward REGGIE.
Where is it, lady -- where've you  got it?
(terrified) I don't know -- I don't know! I don't --
She stops as she sees something.
Instead of a human hand there is a twin-pronged metal one
SCOBIE sees where REGGIE is staring; looks down at it him then lunges at her, raising the hand to strike.
I want it -- give it to me -- it's  mine!
The hand is starting to come down. REGGIE, moving quickly turns and flies out.
(screaming) Peter -- ! Peter -- !

As REGGIE runs out, slamming the door after her, the meta hand crashes against the wooden panel inside the door and splinters through it, visible on this side now. Petrified with fear, REGGIE can only stare dumbly at the protruding claw.
As PETER comes running up to her. He sees the metal hand.
A man -- he tried to kill me!

Pulling her aside, PETER takes hold of the key (still in outside lock) and turns it slowly and quietly. Then, usin all his weight, he slams the door open as far as it will making sure to hold it that way as he steps in.

Inside, PETER pulls back the door and slugs the startled  SCOBIE full on the jaw. His head bangs against the wall b he manages to raise a foot and push PETER violently away, sending him sprawling back, toppling across the bed and o head first, onto the floor on the other side, where he  disappears. Hurrying, SCOBIE puts his foot against the do and pushes it away, ripping his metal hand free. He then rushes to the open window and climbs out.
REGGIE waits anxiously. When she hears nothing, she ginge looks into the room.
(entering cautiously) Peter -- ? (alarmed) Peter! Where are you?
Showing the disarranged room, empty of people. Then, slow PETER's hand appears from behind the bed, shaking groggil REGGIE rushes to him and helps him sit on the bed.
Peter -- are you all right?
I think I sprained my pride. (He looks around) Where'd he go?
Out of the window, I guess -- I didn't  see him.
PETER goes, unsteady on his feet, to the window and looks out. He then turns back.
Lock the door and the window -- and  don't let anyone in except me. I'll  be back in a minute.
Be careful, Peter.
(one leg over the  sill) You took the words right out of my  mouth.
He climbs out.

Outside the window to REGGIE's room is a small, false bal consisting mostly of railing, with barely enough room bet it and the building's facade for a man to stand. PETER ap and looks down over the railing.
SHOOTING STRAIGHT DOWN; there is no one on the street and is too far to jump.

He now looks around. REGGIE's is the last such balcony on one side, but there are two or three on the other. PETER climbs over the railing and, holding on to it with hand, reaches for the railing on the next balcony.
As it stretches for the railing; it is several inches sho of touching it.
As he straightens up and prepares to jump.
From the GROUND. PETER, high above, jumps to the next bal
As he climbs over the railing of the second balcony. He s a light coming through the window and looks in.
Oh!
PETER leaves the window quickly, climbing over the railin on his way to the next balcony. As he does, the following exchange is heard (in British English).
What is it now, Pamela?
It happened again, Henry -- another  strange man peered in the window at  me and then went away.
Bad luck, Pamela.
From the GROUND as PETER jumps to the next balcony.
As he climbs over the rail to the third balcony. There is light coming from this window, too. PETER looks in.
Inside the room are GIDEON, TEX, and SCOBIE in the midst a heated discussion.
That was a dumb move, Herman -- a  dumb move.
And then some. If you'd only told us  you was goin' to her room we could've  kept 'em busy --
-- but sneakin' in there on your own  that-a-way, why, man, you was bound  to get yore tokus kicked. I mean,  what'd you think he'd do -- walk up  'n' shake you by that hand o' yores?
That's right, Herman -- you didn't  leave me much choice.
They all turn toward the window.
As PETER climbs in through the window and joins them.
(to SCOBIE) I didn't hurt you, did I?
SCOBIE shakes his head and turns away.
(eagerly) Never mind that -- did you get the  money?

How could I with the three Marx  Brothers breathing down my neck? You  said you'd let me handle it alone -- ! The girl trusts me. If she's got  it, I'll find out about it. But you've  got to leave me alone.
(to GIDEON and TEX) We took all the chances. The money  belongs to us, not him!
Don't be un-neighborly-like, Herman --  don't forget he done us a little ol'  favor.
Yeah? What's that?
He took care of Charlie for us.
(to PETER) We appreciate it, really we do.
But who asked him? Three shares are  enough -- I'd say he's out!
A third of nothing is nothing, Herman.  Make up your minds -- she's waiting  for me.
(thoughtfully) I don't see how another twenty-four  hours could hurt.
Shoot no, not after all these years.
Then he gets it out of your share,  not mine! Not mine!
SCOBIE turns and storms out of the door, slamming it. GIDEON begins sneezing, takes a bottle of pills from his  pocket and swallows two white tablets.
I suggest you get about your business --  nothing soothes Herman like success.
(chuckling) That's right -- it's like ticklin' a  alligator's belly.
Who's got the room next to hers?
Me. How come?
Get another one, will you? I'm going  to need it.
PETER starts for the door.
If you do find the money -- you won't  forget t' tell us about it, will  you, fella?
(turning at the door) Don't worry.
Oh, I ain't worryin' -- but see this  pudgy little fella here? (indicating GIDEON) He worries -- an' he's even meaner'n  I am.
As she waits anxiously, smoking a cigarette. There is a K at the door.
Who is it?
It's me. Peter.
REGGIE unlocks the door and opens it. PETER enters and sh closes the door again --
There was no trace of him. All right,  Reggie -- suppose you tell me what  this is all about.
There are three men -- he's one of  them -- they think I have something  that belongs to them.
What?
A quarter of a million dollars.
PETER is silent for a moment.
Go on.
That's all.
No, it isn't -- where's the money?
I don't know.  Those men killed  Charles to get it. But he must not  have had it with him on the train.
So they think he left it with you.
But he didn't! I've looked everywhere -- (tears welling) And if I don't find it -- (wailing) Those men going to kill me.
She falls in his arms to be comforted.
No, they won't -- I won't let them.
(sobbing) Please help me, Peter -- you're the  only one I can trust.
Of course I'll help -- I told you I  would, didn't I? Come on now --
He takes out his handkerchief and dries her eyes.
I'm so hungry I could faint. (trying to smile) I've -- I've gotten your suit all  wet.
That's all right -- it's a drip-dry.
Peter, you've got to promise me  something. Promise you'll never lie  the way Charles did. Why do people  have to tell lies?
Usually it's because they want  something -- and they're afraid the  truth won't get it for them.
Do you tell lies?
A pause. The phone rings. REGGIE answers it.
(into the phone) Hello?
SCOBIE holds the receiver in his metal hand.
Mrs. Lampert? -- it's me -- the man  who was in your room a few minutes  ago --
(on the phone) What do you want?
(whispering) Who is it?
(covering the receiver) The man you had the fight with.
(on the phone) Is Dyle with you?
Who?
(on the phone) The man who hit me, lady -- Dyle --  that's his name. What's wrong -- is  he still there?
REGGIE's back is turned to PETER so he can't see her face He watches her.
(on the phone) Yes -- that's right.
What is it, Reggie -- what's he  saying?
She shakes her head.
(on the phone) Don't trust him -- don't tell him  anything. He's after the money.
He hangs up.
Slowly, REGGIE lowers the 'phone from her ear and hangs i up.  She hesitates a moment.
What'd he say?
He -- he said if I didn't give the  money, he'll kill me.
I wouldn't take that too seriously.
I believe what he said.
They're only trying to scare you,  that's all.
How do you know what they're doing?
I don't -- but as long as they think  you have the money, or know where it  is, or have it without knowing where  it is, or don't even know you have  it --
What are you talking about?
You mustn't let what he said bother  you. It was only words.
(softly) Words can hurt very much.
(a pause) Go to sleep -- I'll see you in the  morning.
Don't put yourself out.
Hey -- I'm on your side. Remember  that.
Yes, I'll remember. Good night.
Good night.
He starts out, pausing by the door and examining the hole SCOBIE made in it.
But if you'll take my advice -- (smiling) You'll undress in the closet. Oh,  and if you need me, just bang on the  wall. I'll be next door.

As PETER (now called DYLE) leaves REGGIE's room and close the door. He pauses for a moment, listening, hears nothin then bends down and starts pulling at a loose thread in o of his socks. As usual, the thread unravels -- and unrave and unravels some more until it seems that the entire soc has come unknit. Now, taking the long thread, he bends do near the door and, taking his tie-pin, attaches one end o the thread to the bottom of REGGIE's door. He then runs t thread along the floor to his door (next door) and works underneath.
As DYLE enters, the thread in his hand. He goes to a near table where he attaches the thread to the heavy room key, which he then balances on the extreme edge of the table.
REGGIE is on the phone.

(excited) -- But I am calm, Mr. Bartholomew --  what I called to tell you was there's  someone else -- someone who wasn't  in that photograph you showed me. He  says his name is Peter Joshua -- but  it isn't -- it's Dyle. (a pause) Mr. Bartholomew? -- are you still  there?
BARTHOLOMEW on the phone. He is silent for a moment, his  face troubled.
I don't know who this Mr. Dyle is,  but it's just possible we were wrong  about who killed your husband.
(on the phone) You mean he might have -- Mr.  Bartholomew, I'm catching the next  plane out of here -- I'm not going  to sit here and wait for someone to  make chopped liver out of me!
(on the phone) Where are you now -- can you meet  me? Do you know Les Halles?
(on the phone) Yes, where? (a pause) -- in fifteen minutes. I'll be there.

REGGIE hangs up the phone, picks up her bag, checks her h in the mirror, then starts for the door. She stops as she notices the connecting door leading to the room next door DYLE's room. She goes to it, silently slips out the key a bends to peer through the keyhole.

CLOSE SHOT -- ROOM KEY. The thread attached to it is pull (by the action of REGGIE's door opening) and the key fall to the floor with a clatter.
