As REGGIE sneaks past DYLE's door. When she has passed, t door opens and DYLE appears. REGGIE takes off on the run, turning the corner and starting down the stairs.
Reggie -- !
He starts after her.
It is deserted, except for the sleeping NIGHT PORTER, as  REGGIE comes running down the stairs.
Reggie... !
She turns, looking back towards the sound of his voice, b does not slacken her speed. She runs out the front door.
As REGGIE runs out. She looks up the street, sees a TAXI hails it.
Taxi -- !
It pulls over to the curb. Looking once more over her sho she takes a bill out of her pocket, opens the cab door, s it loudly without getting in and hands the bill to the dr
N'importe ou -- vite! Allez-y!
She jumps back into the shadows of a nearby doorway as th TAXI pulls away. At the same time DYLE runs out of the ho Another TAXI is coming down the street. DYLE hails it  frantically.
Taxi -- ! Taxi -- !
It pulls up and DYLE opens the door.
(pointing) Follow that taxi.
Comment?
Taxi! Follow!
Je ne comprends rien.
Desperately, DYLE reaches into his coat pocket and pulls a small dictionary and begins flipping through the pages.
In the shadows. She lifts her eyes in annoyance.
(finding the word) Suivre -- el taxi!
Ah! Oui, Monsieur.
REGGIE comes out of the shadows, looks after DYLE's taxi, then hails another one which pulls up.
(to DRIVER) Aux Halles -- vite!

REGGIE and BARTHOLOMEW walking. The Central Market is tee with activity -- trucks creeping around other trucks, cas of fruit and vegetables stacked on every inch of sidewalk WORKERS of all types milling around, unloading trucks and stacking crates, little electric carts scooting in and ou and nearby, one of the huge, high-roofed sheds where the  butchers work.
CAMERA LEADING them as they walk.
(looking around) Incredible, isn't it? Zola called it  'le ventre de Paris' -- the womb of  Paris, the belly.
She takes a banana from a nearby stall.
(peeling it) What did you want to see me about,  Mr. Bartholomew?
(leaves a coin on the  crate) Were you followed?
Yes, but I lost him. I really did it  quite brilliantly. I'm beginning to  think women make the best spies.
Agents.
He has a gun, Mr. Bartholomew -- I  saw it.
Who?
Dyle, or whatever his name is.
What does your Mr. Dyle look like,  Mrs. Lampert?
He's hardly my Mr. Dyle.
Describe him.
Well -- he's tall -- over six feet --  rather thin -- in good physical shape,  I'd say -- dark eyes -- quite  handsome, really.
(shaking his head) No.
No, what?
That's not Carson Dyle.
(stopping) Carson?
There's only one Dyle connected with  this affair, Mrs. Lampert -- that's  Carson.
You mean you've known about him all  along? Why didn't you tell me?
BARTHOLOMEW looks at her for a moment, then glances aroun his attention is drawn inside the doorway.
It's enough to make you a vegetarian,  isn't it?
Almost as far as the eye can see, row upon row of beef si hung on hooks.
As REGGIE looks at the hanging beef.
It's just lucky that I'm not hanging  next to one of those things right  now.
She shudders, throws away her banana and turns back to  BARTHOLOMEW.
Mr. Bartholomew -- why didn't you  tell me you knew about Dyle?
I didn't see any point. Dyle's dead.
Dead? Mr. Bartholomew -- maybe you'd  better tell me what this thing's all  about.
Lined up at a zinc bar are several BUTCHERS, their white  smocks stained with blood. REGGIE and BARTHOLOMEW sit at table.
I suppose you're old enough to have  heard of World War Two?
Barely, yes.

In 1944, five members of the O.S.S. --  the military espionage unit -- were  ordered behind the German lines for  the purpose of delivering $250,000  in gold to the French Underground.  The five men --
A WAITER arrives.
Vous desirez?
(smiling) They always do that.
(to the WAITER) Cafe.
Gratinee, choucroute garnie, salade  de pommes -- et un ballon de rouge.
Mrs. Lampert, I really hadn't planned  on spending the entire night here.
Can I at least keep the onion soup?
BARTHOLOMEW shrugs.
(to the WAITER) La soupe tout simplement.
The WAITER nods and goes.
(anxiously) Go on, please -- five men -- $250,000 --  the French Underground --

Yes. The five men. They were, of  course, your husband, Charles, the  three men who showed up at his funeral  yesterday, and Carson Dyle. But  something went wrong and they were  unable to locate their contact. It  must have been at that point that  they decided to steal the money.
Steal it how?

By burying it, and then reporting  that the Germans had captured it.   All they had to do was come back  after the war, dig it up and split  it five ways -- a quarter of a million  dollars with no questions asked.
(fascinated) May I have a cigarette, please?
BARTHOLOMEW pulls out a package and she takes one, looks it and rips off the filter tip. He winces.
I hate these things -- it's like  drinking coffee through a veil.
She puts the other end in her mouth, then picks up the ma and lights it.

Everything went smoothly enough until  after the gold was buried -- then,  before they could get out, they were  ambushed by a German patrol. A machine  gun separated Scobie from his right  hand -- and caught Carson Dyle full  in the stomach.
REGGIE takes another cigarette from his pack, rips off th filter (he winces again) and puts it into her mouth.
What's wrong with that one?
He points to the cigarette she just lit, still practicall brand-new in the ashtray.
Oh. Nothing, I guess. What happened  then?
She hands over the newer one to BARTHOLOMEW, who sadly  examines its mutilated end while REGGIE returns to the fi cigarette.
Have you any idea what these things  cost over here?
Please go on, Mr. Bartholomew --  what happened then?
Scobie was able to travel, but Carson  Dyle was clearly dying, so they --
The WAITER returns with the coffee and onion soup.
La soupe, c'est pour qui?
Pour moi. Go on, Mr. Bartholomew.
The WAITER puts down the cup and bowl and leaves.

Carson was dying so they were forced  to leave him. They finally got back  to the base, made their report, and  waited for the war to end. Only  Charles couldn't wait quite as long  as the others. He beat them back to  the gold, took everything for himself  and disappeared. It's taken Gideon,  Tex and Scobie all this time to catch  up with him again.
But if they stole all that money --  why can't you arrest them?
We know what happened from the bits  and pieces we were able to paste  together -- but we still have no  proof.
But what has all this got to do with  the C.I.O.?
C.I.A., Mrs. Lampert. We're an  extension of the wartime O.S.S. It  was our money and we want it back.
I'm sorry, Mr. Bartholomew, but  nothing you've told me has changed  my mind. I still intend leaving Paris --  tonight.

I wouldn't advise that, Mrs. Lampert.   You'd better consider what happened  to your husband when he tried to  leave. Those men won't be very far  away -- no matter where you go. In  fact, I don't even see any point in  your changing hotels. Please help  us, Mrs. Lampert. Your government is  counting on you.
Well, if I'm going to die, I might  as well do it for my country.
That's the spirit.
Oh, stop it. What do you want me to  do?
We're anxious to know who this man  is -- the one calling himself Dyle.
Maybe he really is Dyle. He could  still be alive.
No, Mrs. Lampert.
But no one actually saw him die.
No, Mrs. Lampert. His death is  registered with the War Department  in Washington.
Oh. Then who's this one?
I don't know -- but I think you'd  better find out, don't you?
Me? Why me?
You're in an ideal position -- he  trusts you. (grinning) Besides, you said yourself, women  make the best spies.
(resigned) Agents.

DYLE leaves the hotel and turns into the Place. A moment  later, REGGIE comes cautiously from the hotel. As she wat DYLE, a SANDWICH-MAN advertising a driving school passes hotel. REGGIE falls in behind him, his tall placard hidin her from view.

First comes DYLE, passing a sidewalk cafe on the corner,  then the SANDWICH-MAN and REGGIE. The SANDWICH-MAN turns  off, leaving REGGIE out in the open. A moment later, DYLE passes a GIRL painting a canvas, her easel set up in the  middle of the sidewalk. He stops when he has passed her a turns to look at her work. REGGIE, not knowing what to do and afraid she will be seen by DYLE, who is now looking h way, spins and sits at the sidewalk cafe's nearest table, her back to DYLE. It is already occupied by a middle-aged TOURIST.

The TOURIST, complete with camera, beret and guide book,  looks up from his coffee, surprised. He stares at REGGIE she stares back. Finally, not knowing what else to do, sh smiles, then takes a portion of his brioche and eats it. He smiles back emptily, not knowing what to make of her. REGGIE turns to look at DYLE.
He has made his judgment of the painting and now moves on

The TOURIST has finally found the courage to speak. As he opens his mouth to make a sound, REGGIE, her eyes on DYLE rises quickly from the table and goes, leaving a very con TOURIST with his mouth open. He blinks, then leaves some  money on the table and starts after her.
REGGIE following DYLE. As she passes the GIRL painting, s cannot resist turning to see the work.
An abstract jumble, nothing recognizable.
As she looks from the painting to reality.
As the scene really looks.
She shrugs, continues after DYLE. Now we see that the TOU in turn, is following her.
(calling) Fraulein --
REGGIE doesn't stop.
Fraulein --
(turning but continuing) What are you doing, following me?  Stop it -- we're going to look like  a parade.
She continues after DYLE. The TOURIST hesitates, then  continues after her.
He goes to the curb and starts to step off, attempting to cross the Rue Danton, but finds the light against him. He turns back in REGGIE's direction.
Realizing she has to do something before DYLE spots her, turns and takes the TOURIST's arm and starts walking with him back toward the cafe.

(smiling and rattling  on) How are you? When did you arrive in  town? Are you enjoying Paris? It's  lovely, isn't it? So many wonderful  things to see and do, it makes one's  head spin to think of it.
She looks back over her shoulder and sees that DYLE is no crossing the Rue Danton, heading for the platform of a bu now stopped at the curb.
(smiling) Fraulein --
REGGIE pulls away from him.
If you don't stop following me I'll  call the police.
She leaves him standing there, more confused than ever, a she starts after DYLE again. DYLE has hopped on the back of the bus as it pulls away. REGGIE hurries across the street, hailing a taxi.
Taxi -- !
DYLE enters. CAMERA PANNING with him to the head of a sta leading downstairs, a sign indicating that it leads to th "MAIL ROOM & TELEPHONES." CAMERA PANS back to the door as REGGIE enters.
DYLE walks to one of several windows. A sign over it read
REGGIE comes down the stairs. Suddenly she stops.
CAMERA ZOOMS in to sign on "D."
A confused look on her face.
As his turn comes, he addresses the CLERK
Dyle, please... D - Y - L - E.
Yes, Mr. Dyle. I remember.
Watching.
The CLERK takes out a bundle of letters and quickly sorts through it.
I'm sorry, Mr. Dyle -- nothing today.
Thanks -- see you soon.
He turns and heads out, starting up the stairs where REGG was but is no longer. As he reaches the fourth or fifth s a VOICE is heard over the loudspeaker.
Mr. Dyle, please -- you're wanted on  the telephone -- Mr. Dyle. Cabin 4.
DYLE stops in his tracks, pondering what to do.
Mr. Dyle. Cabin 4, please.
He stops and comes down the stairs, going to the back of room and into the cabin marked "4."
(picking up the phone) Yes?
CAMERA DOLLIES across an empty cabin to discover REGGIE i the third one, on the phone.
REGGIE on the phone.
DYLE on the phone.
Good morning, Mr. Dyle.
Reggie?
It's the only name I've got. How  about you?
No cat and mouse -- you've got me.  What do you want to know?
Why you lied to me.
I had to -- for all I knew you could  have been in on the whole thing.
Well, you know now, so please tell  me who you are.
But you know my name -- it's Dyle.
Carson Dyle is dead.
Yes, he is. He was my brother.
Your --

The army thinks he was killed in  action by the Germans, but I think  they did it -- Tex, Gideon and Scobie --  and your husband -- because he  wouldn't go along with their scheme  to steal the gold. I think he  threatened to turn them in and they  killed him. I'm trying to prove it.  They think I'm working with them.  But I'm not, and that's the truth.  I'm on your side, Reggie -- please  believe that.

How can I? You lied to me -- the way  Charles did -- and after promising  you wouldn't. Oh, I want to believe  you, Peter... oh, but I can't call  you that anymore, can I? It will  take me a while to get used to your  new name -- which I don't even know  yet. What is it? (pause) Aren't you going to tell me? (pause) Hello -- ?
She opens the door of the cabin and starts out.
As REGGIE steps out of her cabin and starts looking in th others. They are all occupied except one and she looks in it.
The receiver hangs by its cord, swinging back and forth.
As she looks at it, confused.
DYLE and SCOBIE stand together, waiting for the elevator, SCOBIE clearly holding a gun in the pocket of his raincoa
(quietly) If you do anything funny, or try to  talk to anyone, I'll kill you, Dyle --  here and now. Okay?
You'll wreck your raincoat.
The self-service elevator doors open, one or two PASSENGE come out and DYLE and SCOBIE enter. A young GIRL starts i after them.
Next car, please.
He reaches out and presses the top button with his metal  hand. The doors close.

As SCOBIE follows DYLE out of the elevator. SCOBIE looks  around -- there is an open door at the end of a short hal He and DYLE go to it, CAMERA FOLLOWING. Through the door, which SCOBIE closes behind them, is a flight of stairs,  leading up to a second floor.
Okay -- turn around.

DYLE turns to find SCOBIE's gun out of the pocket and poi at him. SCOBIE now transfers it to his metal hand and goe to DYLE, where he proceeds to frisk him. Finding the gun DYLE carries in his inside coat pocket, S removes it. During the following conversation he will sha open the revolving magazine and let the bullets fall out  onto the floor before handing back the emptied gun to DYL Then he will transfer his own gun back to his good hand.
Sit down.
Shrugging, DYLE sits on the third step.
What now?
We wait -- with our mouths shut.
The last EMPLOYEES leave the building as the WATCHMAN loc the front door after them.
In the semi-darkness, DYLE is still sitting on the third  step, SCOBIE still facing him with a gun.
How long do you intend -- ?
I said with the mouth shut.
DYLE yawns wide.
Sorry about that.
Okay -- up there.
DYLE gets to his feet and starts up the stairs, followed SCOBIE. DYLE stops at the door.
Do I knock or something?
Open it.
DYLE opens the door. The stairs continue up.
Keep going.
The view had better be worth it.

A spectacular view of the Paris rooftops and the city lig beyond. DYLE and SCOBIE come out onto a level portion of  roof. On the street side, the roof angles down abruptly i a steep, slate-covered pitch, broken only by two widely  separated oval-shaped dormer windows. Below these is a rain gutter, then nothing -- for seven  stories.
Very pretty. Now what?
I'll give you a chance, Dyle -- which  is more than you'd give me. Where's  the money?
Is that why you dragged me all the  way up here -- to ask me that? She  has it -- you know that.
And I say maybe you both have it!  One more time, Dyle -- where is it?
Supposing I did have it -- which I  don't -- do you really think I'd  hand it over?
You're out, Dyle -- right now!
SCOBIE aims the gun and starts advancing toward DYLE.
Step back.
DYLE turns and looks -- there is nothing behind him but a sheer drop to the street.
Back where?
That's the idea.

Moving quickly, DYLE lashes out and hacks SCOBIE's gun ha with the side of his palm and the gun falls to the roof. Following through, DYLE punches the large man full in the jaw, but instead of falling, SCOBIE wraps his arm around  DYLE, holding on tightly until his head clears. Then, to his amazement, DYLE is lifted into the air and,  unable to break the bear-hold, carried toward the edge of the roof. Working his arms between their two bodies, DYLE suddenly flails them out with all his strength and the ho is broken, but at the price of his coat and the flesh on back as SCOBIE's metal claw rips through both, a wound  extending from the center of DYLE's back to his shoulder. Both men look around for the gun, spot it simultaneously leap for it, both landing short of the mark. Now they gra with one another, each trying to break free and reach for the gun.
Two hands, one real, one metal, inch toward the gun.

The battle is going to SCOBIE whose weight and strength a beginning to tire DYLE, who is now on his back, trying to stop SCOBIE from crawling over him. He has the large man both lapels of the raincoat in a last-ditch effort to hol him. But SCOBIE, his face horribly distorted from the str continues to inch forward toward the gun. Suddenly, DYLE releases his hold. With nothing restrainin him, SCOBIE lurches forward, tumbling past the gun, his  momentum carrying him onto the sloping part of the roof,  where he begins sliding down. SCOBIE beats wildly at the slate with his claw, trying to gouge a grip.
As it slides across the slate, making a hideous scratchin sound and causing sparks to fly.
As he slides over the edge and disappears.
As he watches, hypnotized.
There appears to be no sign of SCOBIE. Then CAMERA ZOOMS FOR A TIGHT CLOSE SHOT OF SCOBIE'S metal hand, gripping t rain gutter at the very edge.
Having seen the claw, he rises and walks to the very edge the level part of the roof.
Herman?
As he hangs, seven stories over the street, by his metal  hand.
Yeah?
He finds it hard to believe.
How are you doing?
How do you think?
If you get bored, try writing 'Love  thy neighbor' a hundred times on the  side of the building.
DYLE turns and leaves going down the stairs.

The HOTEL MANAGER is busy taping a piece of cardboard ove the hole ripped in REGGIE's door by SCOBIE's metal hand t night before. DYLE leaves the elevator and goes to his ow door. The MANAGER eyes him coldly. DYLE "takes" the look.
I didn't do it.
The next time madame forgets her  key, there is another one at the  desk.
DYLE smiles, then enters his room.
He closes the door and starts to remove his torn coat,  wincing.
REGGIE, smoking on the bed, sits up when she hears DYLE m about in his room. She goes to the connecting door, unloc her side, tries the knob, finds it still bolted from his  side and knocks.
Is that you?
DYLE goes to the door, throws back the bolt and opens the door. REGGIE enters.
Didn't anyone ever tell you it's  impolite to -- (seeing his injured  back) What happened?
I met a man with sharp nails.
Scobie?
I left him hanging around the American  Express.
Come on -- I've got something that  stings like crazy.
She leads him into her room.
As REGGIE and DYLE enter from his room. She leads him to bed.
Take off your shirt and lie down.

As REGGIE goes to the bathroom, DYLE takes off his torn s revealing a torn and bloody T-shirt. He lies face downwar on the bed. REGGIE returns, carrying cotton, gauze, tape, scissors, and disinfectant. She sits next to him and lift up his T-shirt to examine the wound.
(wincing) Listen -- all I really want is an  estimate.
It's not so bad. You may not be able  to lie on your back for a few days --  but, then, you can lie from any  position, can't you?
She wets the cotton with disinfectant and begins cleaning the wound. He winces.
Does it hurt?
Haven't you got a bullet I can bite?
She continues working on his back, cleaning it, then band it while they talk.
Are you really Carson Dyle's brother?
Would you like to see my passport?
Your passport! What kind of a proof  is that?
Would you like to see where I was  tattooed?
Sure.
Okay, I'll drive you around there  some day. (his back stinging) Ouch!
Ha ha. You could at least tell me  what your first name is these days.
Alexander.
Is there a Mrs. Dyle?
Yes, but we're divorced.
I thought that was Peter Joshua.
(smiling) I'm no easier to live with than he  was.
(finishing the bandage) There -- you're a new man.
As they continue talking, he rises from the bed and goes  into his own room. REGGIE remains on the bed, watching hi through the open door as he puts on a fresh T-shirt and s
I'm sorry I couldn't tell you the  truth, but I had to find out your  part in all this.
Alex -- how can you tell if someone  is lying or not?
You can't.
There must be some way.

There's an old riddle about two tribes  of Indians -- the Whitefeet always  tell the truth and the Blackfeet  always lie. So one day you meet an  Indian, you ask him if he's a truthful  Whitefoot or a lying Blackfoot? He  tells you he's a truthful Whitefoot,  but which one is he?
Why couldn't you just look at his  feet?
Because he's wearing moccasins.
Oh. Well, then he's a truthful  Whitefoot, of course.
Why not a lying Blackfoot?
(confused) Which one are you?
(entering, smiling) Whitefoot, of course.
Come here.
He goes to the bed.
Sit down.
He sits.
I hope it turns out you're a  Whitefoot, Alex -- I could be very  happy hanging around the tepee.
Reggie -- listen to me --
Oh-oh -- here it comes. The fatherly  talk. You forget I'm already a widow.
So was Juliet -- at fifteen.
I'm not fifteen.
Well, there's your trouble right  there -- you're too old for me.
Why can't you be serious?
There, you said it.
Said what?
Serious. When a man gets to be my  age that's the last word he ever  wants to hear. I don't want to be  serious -- and I especially don't  want you to be.
Okay -- I'll tell you what -- we'll  just sit around all day long being  frivolous -- how about that?
She starts kissing him on the neck, on the chin, on the c
Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.
(pulling back) Okay.
What are you doing?
Cutting it out.
Who told you to do that?
You did.
But I'm not through complaining yet.
Oh. (She starts kissing  him again)
Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.
I think I love you, Alex --
She kisses him on the mouth. The phone rings. He tries to talk as she continues kissing him.
(mumbling) The phone's ringing --
Whoever it is won't give up -- and  neither will I.
The phone continues to ring and she continues to kiss him Finally, REGGIE reaches out to the bedstand and takes the phone off the hook. She brings the receiver up to their m and mumbles into it.
(on phone) Sorry -- I was just -- uh -- nibbling  on something.
TEX speaks into the phone.
Miz Lampert, my buddies 'n me, we'd  oblige it mighty highly if you could  mosey on across the hall 'n chew the  fat with us for a spell.
DYLE is watching her.
(on the phone) Can you give me one good reason why  I should?
(on the phone) Yes, ma'am. A little one -- 'bout  seven or eight years old. Th' little  tyke keeps callin' you his Aunt Reggie --  ain't that cute?
She covers the phone and turns to DYLE in alarm.
They've got Jean-Louis!
That sounds like their problem.
(into the phone) I'll be right there.
(on the phone) We'll be waitin' in room forty-seven,  Miz Lampert -- so you just wiggle on  over.
As REGGIE hangs up.
What day is it?
Tuesday.
Lord, I forgot all about it -- Sylvie  works late Tuesday nights -- she  always leaves him with me. They  wouldn't do anything to a little  boy, would they?
I don't know -- it depends on whether  or not they've already eaten.

CLOSE SHOT -- JEAN-LOUIS. He looks around, uncertainly, f one way, then the other. CAMERA PULLS BACK to show him si on SCOBIE's knee, the large man holding him with his good hand, the metal one in his pocket. TEX sits next to them  while GIDEON nervously paces the floor. When GIDEON begin sneezing he takes the small bottle of pills from his pock and downs one or two, swallowing some water.
Hey, Tex -- move the kid to the other  knee or something, will you? My leg's  going to sleep.
TEX lifts JEAN-LOUIS and puts him down on SCOBIE's other  knee.
Upsy-daisy.
Are you a real cowboy?
Sure am.
Then where is your gun?
(taking out his gun) Right here -- see?
Will you put that thing away!
A KNOCK at the door. GIDEON goes to open it. REGGIE and D enter. She sees JEAN-LOUIS and TEX's gun.
Jean-Louis!
She snatches him off SCOBIE's lap.
Howdy, Miz Lampert.
(glaring at DYLE) Who invited you?
Hello, Herman, it was a happy landing,  I see.
I'd better call Sylvie -- she must  be frantic.
She starts for the door with JEAN-LOUIS. GIDEON blocks he way.
I'm afraid that will have to wait,  Mrs. Lampert.
But his mother --
She isn't going to be anybody's mother  unless you answer some questions. TEX
This ain't no game,  Miz Lampert.
(forcefully) Be quiet, all of you!
The THREE MEN look at him, surprised by his tone.
And stop threatening that boy. He  doesn't have the money. Mrs. Lampert  doesn't either.
Then who does?
I don't know, Herman -- maybe you  do.
Me?
(to TEX) Or you -- (to GIDEON) Or you --
(together) That's the most ridiculous -- ! You gone loco? Listen to the man!
Slowly. Suppose one of you found  Charles here in Paris, followed him,  cornered him on the train, threw him  out the window and took the money.
(after a pause) That's a crock! If one of us did  that he wouldn't hang around here  waiting for the other two to wise  up.

But he'd have to. If he left he'd be  admitting his guilt -- and the others  would know what happened. Whoever it  is has to wait here, pretending to  look for the money, waiting for the  rest of us to give up and go home.  That's when he'll be safe and not a  minute before.
A pause as the THREE MEN look at one another.
Up till now we always figured she  had the money -- but you know so  much about it, maybe you've got it.
Then what am I doing here? You didn't  know anything about me -- I'm the  only one who could have taken it and  kept right on going.
He's just tryin' to throw us off!  They've got it, I tell you! Why don't  we search their rooms?
(exchanging looks  with REGGIE) It's all right with us --
(rising) What are we wastin' time for? Let's  go.
And while we're waiting, we might as  well go through yours.
(stopping) Not my room!
What's wrong, Herman -- have you got  something to hide? (a pause, then smiling) Then I take it there are no  objections.
The THREE MEN look at one another unhappily.
